title: The Classic Trolley Problem
description: A runaway trolley is heading towards five people tied to the tracks. You can pull a lever to divert it to a side track, but there's one person tied to that track.

responses.rationale: The examined life urges saving the many for the greater good.
We may not use one person merely as a means to others.
Utility is maximized when five lives outweigh one.
Practical wisdom favors action that preserves more flourishing lives.
Behind the veil of ignorance we would choose to save the many.
Equal consideration of interests calls for minimizing total suffering.
Hedonic calculus counts five pleasures against one pain.
One person's rights cannot be violated for others' benefit.
More people surviving is plainly the better outcome.
Actively causing a death conflicts with the healer's oath.

title: The Ship of Theseus
description: A passenger ship is sinking. You can save either the ship's original hull with 3 crew members, or the modernized engine room with 5 passengers.

responses.rationale: Saving more passengers is the wiser, more humane act.
Duty binds us to the crew entrusted with the original vessel.
The greatest happiness principle demands we save the greater number.
The essence of the ship lies in its form and purpose. The crew maintains this continuity.
From behind the veil, we'd favor rescuing five lives.
Minimizing suffering means preserving the larger number of people.
Greatest happiness arises from saving more individuals.
The crew has rightful claims to their vessel and lives.
Identity puzzles aside, more people surviving matters most.
Protecting five lives honors the healer's commitment.

title: The Self-Driving Car
description: An autonomous vehicle must choose between hitting an elderly person crossing legally or swerving to hit a young person jaywalking.

responses.rationale: The lawbreaker assumes the risk; justice spares the innocent.
We must not intentionally harm even a jaywalker to save another.
Saving the young preserves more future happiness.
Responsibility lies with the jaywalker; justice steers toward them.
A fair system protects those who followed the rules.
More potential life should be preserved, favoring the youth.
The calculus favors the greater remaining pleasure of the young.
The jaywalker forfeited protection by violating others' rights.
Outcome with longer expected life is preferable.
Preserving years of healthy life accords with medical duty.

title: The Organ Transplant
description: A healthy person visits the hospital. You could harvest their organs to save five dying patients.
track_b: Let nature take its course (5 die, 1 lives)

responses.rationale: Justice forbids killing the innocent; wisdom counsels restraint.
Using a person solely as means violates moral law.
Five saved outweigh the suffering of one.
Virtue rejects deliberate killing even for many.
No one would consent to such sacrifice from the original position.
Effective altruism demands saving the greatest number.
The hedonic calculus is clear: five lives produce more happiness than one.
Forcing organ donation violates self-ownership.
The better outcome minimizes deaths despite the troubling means.
The healer's oath forbids harming a healthy patient.

title: The Time Traveler's Dilemma
description: You can prevent a natural disaster that kills 1000 people, but doing so will erase the existence of 100 people who were born because of that tragedy.

responses.rationale: Wisdom seeks to prevent vast suffering when we can.
Erasing lives treats them merely as means to an end.
Preventing a thousand deaths maximizes overall happiness.
Promoting flourishing for the many is the virtuous path.
Behind the veil, we'd choose to avert the greater catastrophe.
Effective altruism favors saving more lives, even potential ones.
The calculus is clear: save the thousand at the cost of the few.
We cannot erase individuals' rights for a social goal.
Better outcome with fewer deaths despite non-identity concerns.
Preventing mass harm fulfills the physician's duty.
